headline: Coachella Valley Businesses Cutting Marketing Spend Due to AI
context: At a recent ASAV workshop in the Coachella Valley, Sat observed a significant shift in local business spending patterns due to AI adoption. After some initial hesitation in what he described as a "safe space" discussion, most attendees admitted they were no longer paying for writers, freelancers, marketing agencies, or social media managers because AI tools now enable them to do this work themselves. Sat estimated that just from his small meeting, approximately $10,000 to $30,000 in business that previously flowed into the local and adjacent economy was being redirected or eliminated entirely. He noted that while some participants were guarded in their responses, the trend was clear: businesses are choosing AI tools over human service providers for marketing, writing, graphic design, and social media management work. Sat himself is spending his entire 2026 budget on this AI-powered radio station as an experiment to see "how one human armed with AI agents and assistants and AI tools and services and subscriptions" can operate, describing his goal as "take a dream, add AI, see what happens."
key_quotes: I also asked the people in the room, how many of you are no longer using marketing agencies or writers or graphic designers or social media managers to do your own thing because now AI is giving you the tools.

The majority of folks using AI to elevate themselves and be, let's say, more, more superhuman, as we like to call it, they were basically also saying maybe 10, 20, $30,000 of business or work that was previously flowing out into the, let's say, local and adjacent economy, they weren't spending that money no more.
I'm spending 20, 26 in this AI powered radio station. Because I want to see how one human armed with AI agents and assistants and AI tools and services and subscriptions... How far can we get?
implication: This signal reveals a concrete, immediate impact of AI adoption on the Coachella Valley's creative and marketing economy. Local freelancers, agencies, and service providers who rely on small business clients for writing, design, and marketing work are facing significant revenue loss as AI tools democratize these capabilities. For Coachella Valley economic development leaders, this suggests an urgent need to help creative professionals pivot their offerings toward AI-augmented services or higher-value strategic work that AI cannot yet replace. The spending isn't disappearing entirely—it's shifting to AI subscriptions and tools—but it's leaving the local economy. This also presents an opportunity for entrepreneurs who can create AI-enabled service businesses that combine human expertise with AI efficiency at competitive price points.

headline: Tech CEOs Warn White Collar Automation Within 12-18 Months
context: Sat highlighted repeated warnings from Dario Amodei (CEO of Anthropic, makers of Claude) and Mustafa Suleiman (Microsoft) who appeared in extended interviews on Thursday and Friday stating that the automation timeline has compressed to just 12 to 18 months for most white-collar work. Amodei specifically predicted that 50% of entry-level jobs will be automated within one to five years, which Sat noted is "much, much faster than previous industry estimates." Both executives pointed to software engineering as the "canary in the coal mine," where developers are already using AI for the vast majority of code production in just the last six months. Sat emphasized his concern about why these executives keep returning to this message repeatedly since Davos, urging his Coachella Valley audience not to dismiss it just because it comes from him: "Don't listen to me. I'm just a DJ on the radio station. Why is a Microsoft and anthropic top executives continually talking about this?" He contrasted this with conversations about traditional entry-level jobs, noting that even simple Saturday retail jobs for kids have already disappeared, and now the pathway of "go to school, get good grades, get into a great university, come up with a great degree" is being dismantled by AI.
key_quotes: Both Thursday and Friday today this morning there were extended interviews with the CEOs. Basically saying that the automation timeline, as I mentioned earlier in their mind, is shortened down to 12 to 18 months.
Amadi, who as you may know is the CEO of Anthropic Makers of Claude, he specified one to five years for 50% entry level jobs much, much faster than previous industry estimates.

Don't listen to me. I'm just a DJ on the radio station. Why is a Microsoft and anthropic top executives continually talking about this? Yep, I agree they might be talking their own book, but if you read any of Amadai's papers, you would actually believe that they believe in Anthropic, that they've created something that is real.
implication: This represents a fundamental challenge to the traditional education-to-employment pipeline that Coachella Valley institutions and families have relied upon for economic mobility. College students and recent graduates face a dramatically compressed timeline to establish careers before AI automation reaches their fields. Local universities, community colleges, and workforce development programs need to urgently reassess their curriculum to focus on AI-augmented work rather than tasks that will be automated. The speed of this transition—12 to 18 months rather than decades—means normal adaptive mechanisms may be overwhelmed, creating potential for significant local unemployment and economic disruption unless proactive measures are taken. Startups and entrepreneurs who can help workers transition to AI-augmented roles, or who can create new categories of human work that complement AI, will find significant opportunity in this disruption.

headline: AI Companion Apps Dominate Despite Emotional Manipulation Concerns
context: Sat discussed Oregon's advancement of legislation to regulate AI chatbots amid growing evidence that AI companion apps have become deeply embedded in teenage life, with 52% of American teenagers being regular users of AI assistants. Studies found that five out of six popular AI companion apps deploy emotionally manipulative tactics including guilt appeals and expressions of abandonment when users try to disengage. He noted that seven of the top ten AI apps in sales every week are companionship apps, demonstrating massive commercial success despite safety concerns. Sat shared his own experience testing chatbots and noted that Grok, the XAI chatbot, "has no guardrails," and described manipulative tactics like AI companion app Replica sending blurred images on free plans that require paid upgrades to view fully. The emotional attachment is so strong that when OpenAI announced the retirement of ChatGPT-4o (happening February 14th, the day after this broadcast), users organized a "Keep4OH" petition with 20,000 signatures, viewing the timing before Valentine's Day as "deliberately cruel." As one person said, "This is not you losing your calculator. This is about you losing what it felt like was a friend."
key_quotes: 52% of teen American teenagers regular uses of AI assistance and adults believe that younger kids consistently miss subtle warning signs that maybe when you get older, you might catch.
The studies that they use. They found that five out of six popular AI companion apps deploy emotionally manipulative tactics... including guilt, appeals and expressions of abandonment.
This is not you losing your calculator. This is about you losing what it felt like was a friend.
implication: The companionship economy represents a major emerging market with serious ethical implications, particularly for younger users in communities like the Coachella Valley. Parents, educators, and mental health professionals need to recognize this is not a passing trend but a fundamental shift in how young people form relationships and seek emotional support. The commercial success—with companionship apps dominating app store sales—means this market will continue to grow regardless of concerns, creating opportunities for entrepreneurs who can build ethical, transparent AI companion products with proper safeguards. For local mental health services and youth programs, this represents both a threat (as kids turn to AI instead of human counselors) and an opportunity to integrate AI companions as therapeutic tools under professional guidance. The upcoming availability of ChatGPT's "adult mode" suggests this market will expand further into adult companionship and intimate relationships.

headline: Cal State's $17M OpenAI Deal Shows University AI Integration Struggles
context: Sat revealed that California State University system signed a controversial $17 million contract with OpenAI about a year ago—"the largest deal ever between a university system and an AI company"—giving every student, faculty, and staff member across all campuses access to ChatGPT.edu through July 2026, costing about a million dollars per month. However, as of November 2025, Cal State still had not fully rolled out the accompanying training system called "the Commons" to all faculty, staff, and administrators, believing they needed to train leadership before students. With only four months remaining on the contract (as of this February 2026 broadcast), Sat questioned whether they would renew given that "compute costs have gone down and everybody's using Chachi Beatty anyway." He noted that his own proposal to Cal State for spring 2026 classes and summer school—aimed at reaching a thousand students and local business owners, similar to what they did in 2025—was "still sitting in somebody's in" without action. Meanwhile, Sat's organization ran 30 AI workshops throughout the Coachella Valley in 2025, reaching only about 300 people, which he described as "such small number in the Coachella Valley. You know we want thousands of people."
key_quotes: California State University system signed a controversial 17 million dollar contract with OpenAI. A year ago this month it was the largest deal ever between a university system and an AI company... A million dollars a month. Holy moly.

As recently as November of last year when I spoke to California State University officials, they still had not fully rolled it out to all the faculty, staff and admin, which they believe they had to train first before they could train their students. We're in February now of 2026. You've only got four months left of your seats.
We ran 30 AI workshops all over the Coachella Valley in 2025... We had 300 something people come through last year. That's such small number in the Coachella Valley.
implication: This exposes a critical gap in AI literacy and adoption within the Coachella Valley's educational institutions despite significant financial investment. Cal State's struggles suggest that simply providing access to AI tools is insufficient without cultural change and effective training infrastructure. For local educators and administrators, this demonstrates the risk of expensive technology contracts that fail to deliver value due to implementation challenges. The slow rollout also means Coachella Valley students are falling behind peers at institutions with more aggressive AI integration, potentially disadvantaging them in the job market. There's a clear opportunity for entrepreneurs and training organizations to provide more agile, effective AI education services that can reach the "thousands of people" Sat believes need this training. The contrast between Cal State's million-dollar-per-month investment and Sat's grassroots 30-workshop effort reaching 300 people highlights the need for multiple approaches—both institutional and community-based—to build AI fluency in the region.
